google_reviews.text: The exhibits are rotated frequently and always are moving, inspiring, and fascinating. I love the creative space that invites visitors to express their own creativity freely during their visit. The suggested donation to enjoy such an enriching experience is only $5 per person. I really appreciate how accessible such an intentional, luxurious experience has been made to the public. I took my 3 little ones (1, 4, and 6 years) with me on a Thursday around 5pm and we had a beautiful time, mostly in the creativity room. I always capture the most beautiful and fascinating pictures, videos, and memories in this space,  which is always the best part of the whole experience for me. The museum does close at 6pm daily and I personally love an evening museum experience... so a later closing on   occasion would really be a plus. Overall I look forward to my next visit... and it will be soon.
This is a very special art center right here in Oklahoma City.  They host/exhibit world class artists some from Oklahoma. Also an awesome location for meetings and private get togethers.

Love coming here to wander through the exhibits. They change every couple of months and the knowledge and storytelling here is incredible. The contemporary does a stellar job of sharing history through art and design. Plus they offer art classes at the studio school across the street. Great staff, teachers, an facilities. Iâ€™m glad I became a member.

We NEED more community spaces free to the public. Knowledge, arts, and even just a space to sit is necessary in our society. This place runs off of donations to keep doors open, just like the library. So if you're looking for a good spot to visit without breaking the bank I highly implore you stop by the art museum, take a moment, and show some support to one of the few community spaces we have left. Pass the love on ðŸ’šðŸ’šðŸ’š

I love this museum. It's a great venue for plays, as well. It's very community-minded. The museum itself is free. That's right..... this beautiful architecture and museum entry is free. They host plays  in one of their stage areas... the place do cost, but not much... and they are lovely productions.

museums.content_summary: 108|Contemporary is a captivating gem in Oklahoma City that celebrates the ever-evolving landscape of contemporary art. With dynamic exhibitions featuring emerging artists and innovative crafts, this museum provides a fresh perspective on modern creativity making it a must-visit for art enthusiasts and casual visitors alike.
museums.content_description: **108|Contemporary** stands out as a vibrant hub for cutting-edge art and craft in the heart of Oklahoma City. This museum uniquely focuses on contemporary artistic expressions, showcasing work from both established and emerging artists who challenge traditional boundaries. Visitors are invited to experience thought-provoking installations and dynamic exhibitions that provoke dialogue and inspire creativity. The museum's commitment to the art of today ensures that each visit offers something new and exciting, with exhibitions changing regularly throughout the year. Expect to see works that reflect the complexity of modern life, addressing themes like identity, technology, and social issues through the lens of contemporary craft and art forms. Additionally, the upcoming exhibition, *The State of Craft 2025*, promises to immerse guests in innovative artworks that redefine craftsmanship, running from December 5, 2025, to January 24, 2026. Visitors should also mark their calendars for *Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right* and *Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies*â€”these exhibitions, taking place in early 2026, will further elevate the museum's programming and showcase the talents of artists who are reshaping the craft landscape. In addition to the stunning art, guests can enjoy carefully curated public events, workshops, and discussions aimed at fostering a deeper understanding of contemporary artistic practices. Each corner of 108|Contemporary invites exploration and appreciation, making it not just a museum but a vital part of Oklahoma City's cultural ecosystem.

google_reviews.text:
Nice little wartime museum.  The submarine was neat to see but due to the current condition we couldn't go inside.  However, the museum curator provided a discount, which was unnecessary, but a nice gesture.

We were told that the museum will be getting a new facility in the near future so hoping to make a day trip down to see it when that occurs.

Very informative and interesting. Lots of original memorabilia both inside and outside to peruse. The only downside is that being in a flood plain, you cannot get onto the ship at this time as itâ€™s not safe to. The volunteer Curator said there are federal funds allotted to secure it, but wonâ€™t happen overnight.
PSâ€” we saw a bald eagle overhead too.

I highly recommend visiting the Muskogee war memorial. This was our second time attending and once again it did not disappoint. For just $3 you get to enjoy the museum and view the USS Batfish amongst other large war machines. Jim is the best tour guide! His knowledge and passion are above and beyond expectations.

Even though the boat itself is closed, the rest of the memorial is still open Friday to Sunday! There's more to see than just the Batfish, including over a dozen different artifacts ranging from torpedoes, to naval mines, to 5-inch naval guns, and more! The volunteer there was extremely friendly and was happy to answer any questions I had.
If you're visiting I recommend donating extra, as entry is only $3/person at the moment due to the submarine's closure, and they're trying to raise funds in preparation to move her to a permanent, more submarine friendly, location down the Arkansas River.

A charming little museum in the town where squares can definitely have a ball! The best part of this visit was James A. Erb, Jr. He is a POW survivor with an amazing story which I won't spoil, but get him to tell them to you if you visit. There was also the submarine which is currently no visitable. You still can get a good external view of it though and go out and walk around it. This place has a tribute to every U.S. submarine that has fallen with a detailed story of the ship's adventures and her crew's service for those downed during World War I. The museum itself is manageably sized with a side room featuring some hands=on exhibits. Be aware of the Friday- and Weekend- only hours! I would recommend this museum for any history buffs and military history history buffs especially.

museums.content_summary: Discover a unique blend of history and nature at the Muskogee War Memorial Park, home of the USS Batfish. This captivating destination features a lush botanical garden alongside a historical submarine, offering visitors a chance to explore both the beauty of nature and the depth of maritime history in one remarkable spot.
museums.content_description: **Muskogee War Memorial Park: Home of the USS Batfish** is a truly remarkable destination that deftly intertwines the serene beauty of a botanical garden with the gripping history of warfare at sea. Nestled in the heart of Muskogee, this park not only showcases stunning landscapes but also pays homage to the sacrifices made by those who served in the U.S. Navy through the iconic submarine, the USS Batfish. This WWII vessel provides a rare glimpse into maritime history, inviting visitors to explore its corridors and imagine the stories of valor that resonate within its walls. The juxtaposition of the tranquil garden settings against the rugged exterior of the submarine creates an engaging atmosphere that is both educational and reflective. Visitors can wander through the well-maintained paths of vibrant flora, offering a perfect respite for those seeking natureâ€™s tranquility amidst the historical significance of the park. A visit during seasonal blooms will awaken your senses with an array of colors and scents, all while the rich history of the USS Batfish looms nearby, ready to be uncovered. The contrast between the serenity of the botanical spaces and the powerful presence of the submarine ensures a memorable and engaging outing. Families, history enthusiasts, and nature lovers will find much to appreciate as they immerse themselves in the beauty and bravery that this unique park has to offer. **Muskogee War Memorial Park** promises an enriching experience for all agesâ€”a true testament to the duality of life and its histories entwined in nature and valor. Itâ€™s not just a park; itâ€™s a living tribute that celebrates both the past and the present, making it a must-visit destination on your trip to Muskogee.
content_highlights: Explore the historic USS Batfish submarine, a WWII veteran
Stroll through beautifully landscaped botanical gardens
Experience seasonal blooms and diverse plant species
Learn about naval history and memorials dedicated to veterans
Enjoy family-friendly activities and educational programs

museums.content_summary: The National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum in Oklahoma City offers a captivating glimpse into the American West, showcasing its rich history, vibrant art, and cowboy culture. With its extensive collections and engaging exhibits, this museum invites you to celebrate the spirit of the West like never before.
museums.content_description:
**The National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum** stands as a testament to the enduring legacy and culture of the American West. Located in Oklahoma City, this museum houses a remarkable collection of over 28,000 artifacts that vividly tell the story of cowboy life, Western art, and Native American heritage. As you step inside, youâ€™re greeted by the intricate architecture that mirrors the rugged beauty of the West, featuring stunning sandstone walls and expansive galleries filled with natural light that enhance the experience of each exhibit. From historical artifacts to modern Western art, every corner of the museum resonates with the essence of the frontier spirit.  

One of the museum's standout features is its collection of Western art, including works by renowned artists like Frederic Remington and Charles M. Russell. These masterpieces capture the unparalleled landscape and diverse personalities that defined the era. The museum also offers immersive experiences for visitors, such as the live demonstration of traditional cowboy skills or curated exhibitions like 'The State of Craft', showcasing contemporary artisans who draw inspiration from Western themes. You can stroll through the beautifully landscaped gardens or visit the Hall of Great Westerners, which honors those who have significantly impacted Western history. Whether you're a history enthusiast, an art lover, or simply curious about cowboy culture, the **National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum** promises an enriching experience that pays homage to one of America's most captivating chapters.  

Be sure to visit during unique exhibitions, like the upcoming *Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right* or *Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies*, providing fresh insights into the intersection of art and Western culture. This museum is a vibrant celebration of the West, a journey back in time that visitors of all ages will find inspiring and memorable.
content_highlights: Over 28,000 artifacts related to cowboy life and Western culture
Impressive collection of Western art by artists like Frederic Remington
Interactive exhibitions and live demonstrations of cowboy skills
Beautifully landscaped gardens and outdoor spaces
Hall of Great Westerners honoring influential figures in Western history

google_reviews.text: This was my first trip to the museum.  And it was amazing. I had a private tour from Josh. His knowledge of every piece, and every gallery was exceptional. I learned so much from him. Every interaction with other staffers were welcoming and very friendly. I believe that everyone, no matter your age visit the Oklahoma City Museum. There's a gift shop, and food service that will appeal to all tastes.

We had a fantastic time at the museum.   We went to the special exhibit they had for Ansel Adams, and I didn't expect the exhibit to be as large as it was.  They have a variety of his photos spanning the length of his life as well as photos other took of Ansel. We also stopped by the permanent Chihuly exhibit, and they have several pieces I've never seen before.  It's a fantastic selection, and we hope to come back again

Easy in and out. Free wheelchairs. Staff super friendly and helpful.  The galleries are clean, smell nice and are plenty roomy, even on abusy day. Admission is a bit high imho, but still a nice visit.

Lots of available parking, but you have to pay. It was a little confusing for us to figure out where the entrance was. We mistakenly went in first to the store. Then the theater. We finally figured out the correct entrance.

The exhibits were wonderful. There are three stories, an exhibit on each. Nice layout, well lit.
So beautiful! Staff is very friendly and spaces are clean and well kept. The kids/family area is perfect for the littles too!

museums.content_summary: In the heart of downtown, the Oklahoma City Museum of Art pairs big-city ambition with an approachable, visitor-friendly scale. Come for the museumâ€™s standout glass and modern collections, stay for thoughtfully curated exhibitions and an architecture-forward building that feels made for lingering. Whether youâ€™re planning a focused art pilgrimage or a restorative afternoon between Oklahoma City sights, this regional anchor delivers strong gallery experiences, excellent design, and a lively calendar that rewards repeat visits.
museums.content_description:
**Oklahoma City Museum of Art (OKCMOA)** is the cityâ€™s flagship art stopâ€”an art-loverâ€™s museum with a confident curatorial voice and a downtown setting that makes it easy to fold into a weekend itinerary. While its reputation is proudly regional, the experience feels expansive: galleries are paced for unhurried looking, with clear sightlines, strong lighting, and changing exhibitions that keep the visit fresh. The museumâ€™s schedule often spotlights contemporary makers and craft-forward practicesâ€”perfect for travelers who like to see whatâ€™s happening *now* rather than only the canonical greatest hits.

A major draw is the museumâ€™s celebrated glass holdings, anchored by the spectacular **Dale Chihuly** installation **â€œEleanor Blake Kirkpatrick Memorial Towerâ€**â€”a soaring, immersive centerpiece that many visitors remember as vividly as any painting. Beyond glass, expect rotating displays that can range from modern and contemporary work to photography and design-leaning shows, with a particular strength in exhibitions that connect regional perspectives to broader currents in *contemporary art* and *craft*.

Architecturally, the museum reads as purpose-built for visual pleasure: clean modern lines, generous gallery proportions, and calm transitions between spaces. For art enthusiasts, the visitor experience is the pointâ€”come early for quieter rooms, revisit favorite works after youâ€™ve calibrated your eye, and plan around special exhibitions such as **â€œThe State of Craft 2025â€** (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026). Note the **winter break closure (Dec 23, 2025â€“Jan 1, 2026)** when timing your trip.
content_highlights: Dale Chihulyâ€™s dramatic â€œEleanor Blake Kirkpatrick Memorial Tower,â€ a must-see immersive glass installation
Strong emphasis on contemporary exhibitions, including craft-focused programming like â€œThe State of Craft 2025â€
Downtown Oklahoma City location thatâ€™s easy to pair with dining, hotels, and evening plans
Modern, gallery-forward architecture with clean sightlines and lighting designed for close looking
A repeat-visit museum: frequent rotating shows (e.g., Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right; Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies) that refresh the experience

museums.open_hour_notes: Open 11 a.m.-6 p.m. Wednesday-Monday. Closed Tuesdays and holidays.
museums.content_summary: Oklahoma Contemporary Arts Center is Oklahoma Cityâ€™s hub for art happening nowâ€”where you visit for whatâ€™s new, bold, and in conversation with the present. Expect exhibition-driven programming that spotlights contemporary craft, experimental media, and timely ideas, paired with an energetic, welcoming atmosphere. For art lovers planning a trip, itâ€™s a reliable place to catch rotating shows, discover regional and national artists, and experience a museum that feels like a living studio rather than a static collection.
museums.content_description:
**Oklahoma Contemporary Arts Center** is best experienced as a venue for discovery: a museum centered on **rotating, contemporary exhibitions** rather than a single canonical collection. That focus makes each visit feel current and time-specificâ€”ideal for travelers who like to plan around whatâ€™s on view. Recent and upcoming programming points to a strong interest in **contemporary craft and material experimentation**, as seen in *The State of Craft 2025* (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026), and in artist-centered exhibitions such as **Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right** (Feb 6â€“Mar 21, 2026) and **Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies** (Apr 3â€“May 23, 2026). Expect shows that foreground process, technique, and conceptâ€”where the pleasure of looking is inseparable from how something is made and what itâ€™s trying to say.

Architecturally, the center reads as a contemporary, light-filled cultural anchorâ€”an appropriate frame for work that often leans into *installation*, *new media*, and scale. Galleries are designed for flexibility, letting curators shift from intimate craft detail to room-filling environments with ease. For visitors, that translates into an experience thatâ€™s less about ticking off famous masterpieces and more about **spending time with ideas**: reading walls, revisiting a piece after youâ€™ve seen the room, and noticing how materials behave under changing light.

For art enthusiasts, the biggest reward is the sense of immediacyâ€”an institution tuned to what artists are making now, with the cityâ€™s creative energy close at hand. Check the calendar before you go (note the winter break closure Dec 23, 2025â€“Jan 1, 2026), and plan to linger: the best visits here are unhurried, curious, and open to surprise.
content_highlights: Exhibition-led museum experience focused on contemporary art rather than a static permanent display
The State of Craft 2025 (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026), spotlighting contemporary craft practices and material innovation
Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right (Feb 6â€“Mar 21, 2026), a focused artist presentation for deeper looking
Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies (Apr 3â€“May 23, 2026), exploring artâ€™s relationship to environment and systems
Flexible contemporary galleries suited to installation, new media, and large-scale worksâ€”ideal for immersive viewing

museums.content_summary: The Stillwater History Museum at the Sheerar offers a unique glimpse into the rich heritage and culture of Stillwater, Oklahoma. Its engaging exhibitions and welcoming atmosphere make it a must-visit for anyone interested in local history, artistic expression, and community storytelling.
museums.content_description: **Stillwater History Museum at the Sheerar** is a treasure trove of local history, art, and culture nestled in the heart of Stillwater, Oklahoma. The museum not only showcases the intriguing past of the area but also acts as a vibrant community hub that celebrates both historical and contemporary artistic endeavors. With a charming blend of *historical artifacts* and *modern exhibitions*, visitors are invited to explore the stories that have shaped this vibrant community. Current exhibitions, like *Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right* and *Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies*, highlight the dynamic dialogue between artistry and the natural world, aiming to inspire visitors to reflect on their own connections to place and identity. These rotating exhibitions ensure that each visit reveals something new and exciting, making it a worthwhile destination time and again.Â Ultimately, **The Stillwater History Museum at the Sheerar** reflects the essence of Stillwaterâ€”a town rich in tradition and brimming with creativity.Â Â The architecture of the museum itself is a charming reminder of the town's history. Set in a graceful building that adds to the character of the area, visitors will appreciate the blend of traditional and contemporary design that complements the museum's diverse offerings. Families and individual travelers alike will find immersive experiences here, thanks to engaging programs that cater to all ages, from hands-on workshops to interactive tours. The warm, inviting atmosphere encourages conversation and connection, making it a perfect stop for those looking to delve deeper into Oklahoma's fascinating history and culture. Don't miss out on the unique opportunity to engage with local stories and artistic perspectivesâ€”plan your visit to **Stillwater History Museum at the Sheerar** today!Â Â
content_highlights: Rotating exhibitions featuring local, contemporary artists
Rich collections of Stillwater's history and cultural artifacts
Educational programs and workshops for all ages
Architectural charm reflecting the town's historical character
Community-focused events that foster connection and storytelling

google_reviews.text: Such a cute little local museum!  The actual museum itself isn't very large so it takes about 45-60 minutes to walk through and see everything. There's a little bit about several periods in Broken Arrow's history, and it was all very interesting and informative. Thank you for letting us explore the history of Broken Arrow!
Nice small museum. Loved the mural on the wall outside. It's 8 bucks to go upstairs not 5. They need to change it.

I found this museum very wonderful! It is extremely well done with a great tribute to the KATY railroad. They had a very moving tribute to the early people who started the city of Broken Arrow. Everything from sports to Military service.

Just moved to the rose district here in Broken Arrow and just had to visit this museum! Even from the outside the beautiful mural pulls you in. The price of admission is $5 which is a great deal for the content you find in the museum itself. Definitely recommend visiting for any history buff.
I went in with low expectations but left feeling fascinated by the local history. Recommended for folks with roots in Broken Arrow.

museums.content_summary: The Museum Broken Arrow is a hidden gem that brings the world of contemporary craft to life through innovative exhibitions and engaging community programs. With its rotating schedule of diverse artists and unique installations, it's a must-visit destination for those seeking inspiration and creativity in the heart of Oklahoma.
museums.content_description:
**The Museum Broken Arrow** stands out as a vibrant space dedicated to the celebration of contemporary craft, showcasing the works of innovative artists who push the boundaries of traditional techniques. The museum offers a rotating lineup of exhibitions, ensuring that every visit brings something fresh and new. From stunning fiber arts to intricate ceramic creations, the ever-changing displays invite guests to explore the depth and breadth of modern craftsmanship. The upcoming exhibition, *The State of Craft 2025*, promises to be a hallmark event, highlighting the vital role craft plays in artistic expression today. It will run from December 5, 2025, to January 24, 2026, offering a timely glimpse into the future of this dynamic art form. Visitors planning their trip should note the museumâ€™s winter break closure from December 23, 2025, to January 1, 2026, when it will pause to refresh its vision for the new year.Â Â 

In addition to its exhibitions, **The Museum Broken Arrow** fosters a sense of community through a variety of educational programs and workshops designed for all ages. Local artists often collaborate with the museum, leading hands-on sessions that allow participants to delve into crafting techniques, from pottery to textiles. The museumâ€™s modern architecture complements its mission, featuring open spaces filled with natural light that enhance the viewing experience. With a commitment to both excellence and accessibility, this museum not only showcases art but also inspires creativity and appreciation for the arts in the local community and beyond. Whether you are an art aficionado or simply looking for a fun and educational activity, a trip to **The Museum Broken Arrow** will leave you enriched and inspired.
content_highlights: Rotating exhibitions of contemporary craft showcasing diverse artistic practices
Educational workshops and hands-on sessions led by local artists
The upcoming exhibition, *The State of Craft 2025*, featuring emerging trends
Engaging community programs that connect art with the public
Modern architectural design that enhances the visitor experience

google_reviews.text: The trip was enjoyable, and we appreciated the opportunity to explore new places. Some of us chose to relax near the water, which was quite refreshing. The curated museum provided a fascinating glimpse into history and culture. We all had a day filled with diverse activities. It was a lovely experience overall, allowing everyone to pursue their interests.

The collection of artifacts in the Museum of the Red River is impressive.  It is hard to believe that admission is free.  If you enjoy history, archeological finds, and art, go visit this place.  Highly recommend it!

A wonderful museum, I highly recommend visiting! So much history and artifacts from all over the world. They have a massive collection of woven baskets.
There are some fun, interactive things for the kids
Very cool and informative museum. I hope they grow and expand. Some really neat pieces. The kids of course loved the dinosaur skeleton.
Interesting building, free admission, variety of exhibits. Definitely worth the stop.

museums.content_summary: The Museum of the Red River in Idabel offers a distinct experience for art and history enthusiasts, showcasing a unique blend of regional culture and contemporary craft. From captivating exhibitions to interactive installations, this museum invites visitors to explore the rich heritage of the Red River region, making it a must-visit stop for travelers seeking inspiration and creativity.
museums.content_description:
**The Museum of the Red River** stands as a vibrant testament to the artistic and cultural tapestry of southeastern Oklahoma. Nestled in Idabel, this museum is not only a repository of historical artifacts but also a dynamic space where contemporary craft and traditional art converge. With a commitment to celebrating local heritage and the natural environment of the Red River valley, it is a unique destination for art lovers and curious travelers alike. Here, exhibitions like *The State of Craft 2025* present a platform for innovative artists, showcasing works that engage with community and nature, running from December 5, 2025, to January 24, 2026. The museum also features seasonal exhibitions by contemporary artists such as Alicia Kelly and Shawn Smith, further enriching its offerings with diverse perspectives and styles.Â Â 

The **Museum of the Red River**â€™s architecture is thoughtfully designed to harmonize with its natural surroundings, featuring both indoor and outdoor spaces that encourage contemplation and connection to the environment. Visitors can wander through thoughtfully curated collections that speak to the cultural significance of the region, providing context and insights into local history. Each visit promises an enriched experience, where art meets education, and every corner invites discovery. Whether youâ€™re admiring the intricate craftsmanship of featured artists or participating in engaging workshops, this museum ensures that creativity thrives and stories are shared along the banks of the Red River.
content_highlights: Dynamic contemporary exhibitions like *The State of Craft 2025*
Seasonal artist showcases featuring local and national talent
Architectural design blending with the natural landscape
Interactive installations and workshops for all ages
Celebration of the rich heritage of the Red River region

google_reviews.text: Went for the first time, and it was pretty cool. There are so many cool different things to see and facts to read about. 2 stories in the museum itself. They have planes, helicopters, interactive setups, and games for kids. There is also a playground and an airplane you can board. The planetarium show was awesome, and I would love to see all of the shows. Definitely recommend it, and it's pretty cheap admission.
We had such a great time here learning about aircraft history in the local area. The children enjoyed getting to fly the hot air balloon and land the space shuttle.

They lock the doors as soon as the show starts even when no one is in there. We came for nothing. The guy that let us know seems very condescending saying awwww. We enjoyed the Oklahoma aquarium though

The website is user friendly, easy to purchase tickets.  Small museum with a big punch, lots of hands on activities for all ages.  Outside playground and great exhibits where you can get up close.  Highly recommend
Small air and space museum but an awesome place to visit. Lots of amazing aircrafts to see. The Planetarium was enjoyable.  Well worth visiting while in Tulsa

museums.content_summary: Explore the skies and beyond at the Tulsa Air and Space Museum & Planetarium, where aviation history meets cosmic exploration. Engage with immersive exhibits, learn about aviation pioneers, and enjoy spectacular planetarium shows that will ignite your curiosity about the universe.
museums.content_description: **Tulsa Air and Space Museum & Planetarium** is a remarkable destination that caters to enthusiasts of aviation, space exploration, and the wonders of science. Nestled in the heart of Tulsa, this museum not only showcases a rich collection of aircraft and aerospace artifacts but also provides a state-of-the-art planetarium experience. Visitors will be captivated by the unique blend of history and technology, as they witness exhibits detailing the evolution of flight and the incredible journeys of space exploration. With interactive displays, educational programs, and a commitment to inspiring the next generation of aviators and astronauts, the museum stands out as a cornerstone of scientific education in Oklahoma.Â In the planetarium, enjoy stunning digital presentations that bring the cosmos to life, allowing you to explore distant galaxies and understand the vastness of our universe like never before.Â Â This space offers not just a glimpse into the past but a pathway to the future of aeronautics and astronomy.Â As you wander through the exhibits, you might find yourself in awe of the *Tulsan contributions* to aviation and space endeavors, lending a unique local flavor to the international narrative of flight and exploration.Â The **Tulsa Air and Space Museum** isn't just a repository of historical artifacts; it's a dynamic space designed for discovery, learning, and boundless inspiration.Â From flight simulations to captivating planetarium shows, the visitor experience is enriched by knowledgeable staff ready to guide you through your journey. Whether you're a family looking for a fun day out or a space aficionado searching for your next fix, this museum promises a memorable experience for all.Â Â
content_highlights: Interactive exhibits on aviation and space exploration
Stunning planetarium shows with cutting-edge technology
Historical aircraft and space artifacts unique to Tulsa
Educational programs for all ages
Flight simulators offering hands-on experiences

museums.content_summary: The Will Rogers Memorial Museums in Claremore, Oklahoma, is a unique tribute to the beloved humorist, actor, and cowboy. Through an extensive collection of memorabilia and exhibits, visitors can immerse themselves in the life and legacy of one of America's most cherished cultural icons.
museums.content_description: **Will Rogers Memorial Museums** is more than just a museum; it's a heartfelt homage to the life of Will Rogers, who remains a symbol of American wit and wisdom. Located in Claremore, Oklahoma, this extraordinary museum complex showcases an extensive collection of artifacts, photographs, and documents that narrate the story of a man whose humor transcended generations. The museum is set against the backdrop of beautifully landscaped grounds that also feature a stunning memorial to Rogers, giving visitors a serene environment to reflect on his legacy. Each exhibit is designed to engage, educate, and entertain, providing a comprehensive look at the multifaceted life of this remarkable individual.Â Â In addition to the core collections, the museums host rotating exhibitions, such as *The State of Craft 2025*, and other contemporary showcases like **Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right**, allowing guests to experience a dynamic blend of past and present artistic expressions.Â Â The architecture of the museum itself complements its purposeâ€”each building pays tribute to the western spirit Rogers embodied, with design elements that nod to Native American and cowboy cultures. As you explore the galleries, youâ€™ll encounter touching mementos that connect Rogers' heritage to his impact on American culture, offering insights into his roles as an entertainer, writer, and political commentator. The museum also fosters a warm, welcoming atmosphere where laughter reigns, echoing Rogers' own words: 'I never met a man I didnâ€™t like.' Don't miss out on the opportunity to walk the grounds, which include his final resting place, where visitors can pay their respects to a true American icon.Â Â Whether you're an admirer of Will Rogers, a fan of American history, or simply looking for a meaningful experience, the Will Rogers Memorial Museums provide an unforgettable journey through the life of one of America's most endearing figures.Â Â Visiting this museum is not just about viewing exhibits; it's about connecting with the spirit of a man whose humor and philosophy continue to inspire.Â Â **Will Rogers Memorial Museums** is a destination where history, art, and laughter converge, making it a must-visit for travelers exploring the heart of Oklahoma.
content_highlights: Comprehensive collection of Will Rogers memorabilia
Beautifully landscaped grounds including Rogers' final resting place
Diverse rotating exhibitions showcasing contemporary art
Architectural design that reflects western heritage
Interactive exhibits that engage visitors in Will Rogers' legacy

museums.content_summary: Nestled in the picturesque foothills of the Osage Hills, the **Woolaroc Museum and Wildlife Preserve** offers a unique blend of art, history, and wildlife. Visitors can explore a stunning collection of Western art and artifacts while enjoying vibrant experiences in a wildlife preserve, making it an unforgettable destination for nature and culture lovers alike.
museums.content_description:
**Woolaroc Museum and Wildlife Preserve** invites visitors into a realm where art, history, and wildlife converge harmoniously. Founded in the 1920s by oilman Frank Phillips, this expansive estate and museum reflect his passion for the American West. The museum itself boasts an impressive collection that includes over 4,000 items, from *Native American artifacts* to *Western paintings* and sculptures by renowned artists. Each piece illustrates the rich tapestry of cultural heritage that defines the American landscape. Visitors can wander through the museum's thoughtfully curated exhibits, immersing themselves in the story of the West while admiring the craftsmanship of its artists. Itâ€™s a journey through time that celebrates both the natural world and the artistic genius captured within it.Â Â 

The **Woolaroc Wildlife Preserve**, spanning over 3,700 acres, complements the museum with its stunning natural beauty and diverse wildlife. Guests can take a scenic drive or join guided tours to observe bison, elk, and even longhorn cattle in their natural habitats, offering a truly immersive experience into the beauty of the rugged Oklahoma wilderness. Seasonal events, educational programs, and wildlife encounters make this an interactive destination. Whether itâ€™s a peaceful walk through the grounds or a ride through the preserve, each visit to **Woolaroc** promises unique memories and a deeper appreciation for the tranquility of nature intertwined with enriching cultural explorations.
content_highlights: Stunning collection of Western art and artifacts
Vast wildlife preserve featuring bison, elk, and longhorn cattle
Rich history tied to oilman Frank Phillips
Interactive programs and seasonal events
Beautifully landscaped grounds ideal for nature walks

museums.content_summary: In Bartlesville, the Price Tower Arts Center pairs an art-loverâ€™s museum visit with a pilgrimage to one of Frank Lloyd Wrightâ€™s most distinctive buildings. Come for the rotating exhibitionsâ€”often focused on contemporary craft, ecology, and material experimentationâ€”and stay for the experience of seeing art in a landmark of American modern architecture. With an intimate, local scale and a strong program of seasonal shows, itâ€™s a rewarding stop for travelers who like their museums thoughtful, design-forward, and deeply tied to place.
museums.content_description:
**Price Tower Arts Center** is a small but culturally resonant destination in Bartlesvilleâ€”especially for visitors who want more than a standard gallery circuit. Rather than relying on a fixed â€œgreatest hitsâ€ permanent collection, the museumâ€™s energy comes from **changing exhibitions and artist-centered projects**, such as *The State of Craft 2025* (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026) and solo shows including **Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right** (Feb 6â€“Mar 21, 2026) and **Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies** (Apr 3â€“May 23, 2026). The programming leans into *craft* and contemporary practicesâ€”work that rewards close looking at process, materials, and the ideas embedded in making.

For architecture-minded art travelers, the setting is a major part of the draw: **Price Tower**, designed by **Frank Lloyd Wright**, is an Oklahoma icon and a rare chance to encounter art within a work of *American modernism* that feels sculptural and verticalâ€”more â€œinhabited design objectâ€ than neutral white cube. Expect a viewing experience shaped by the buildingâ€™s character: shifting sightlines, intimate rooms, and moments where architecture and exhibition design converse.

Plan your visit like you would a focused gallery outing: check the schedule (noting the **winter break closure, Dec 23â€“Jan 1**) and give yourself time to absorb both the **art on view** and the **architecture itself**. For enthusiasts of contemporary craft, Wright devotees, and travelers tracing Oklahomaâ€™s cultural map, itâ€™s a satisfying, place-specific museum stop.
content_highlights: Exhibition-driven program spotlighting contemporary craft and material-based practices (e.g., The State of Craft 2025)
Frank Lloyd Wrightâ€™s Price Tower as a landmark setting that shapes how you experience the art
Seasonal roster of focused solo exhibitions (Alicia Kelly; Shawn Smith) ideal for repeat visits
Intimate, local museum scaleâ€”good for slow looking and close engagement with technique and process
Travel-friendly planning details, including winter break closure dates and clearly scheduled show runs

museums.content_summary: The Chisholm Trail Heritage Center is a must-see destination for anyone fascinated by the history of the American West. This museum vividly brings to life the stories of cattle drives, pioneers, and the rich cultural tapestry of the region, making it a unique and immersive experience for visitors of all ages.
museums.content_description:
**Chisholm Trail Heritage Center** offers a captivating glimpse into the history of one of the most significant cattle trails in the United States. Nestled in Duncan, Oklahoma, this historic preservation museum expertly showcases the extraordinary journey of cattle drives in the 19th century, blending interactive exhibits with authentic artifacts. Visitors can step back in time and experience life on the trail, where theyâ€™ll learn about the brave cowboys and cattlemen who played a pivotal role in shaping the American landscape. The center's engaging displays are designed to resonate with history enthusiasts, families, and anyone curious about the American frontier experience.Â Â 

The museumâ€™s architecture harmoniously echoes its historic subject matter, featuring visuals that reflect the rugged yet bold spirit of the Old West. Guests can enjoy immersive exhibits such as a life-size cattle drive diorama, enhancing their understanding of this unique chapter in American history. The **Chisholm Trail Heritage Center** also offers a diverse range of educational programs and special events, ensuring that every visit is dynamic and enriching. Whether youâ€™re intrigued by the cultural exchanges along the trail or the challenges faced by pioneers, this museum provides an inspiring and informative adventure. Donâ€™t miss the opportunity to delve into the heart of the American West and take home enduring stories of innovation, resilience, and discovery.
content_highlights: Interactive exhibits showcasing life on the Chisholm Trail
Authentic artifacts from the cattle driving era
Life-size cattle drive diorama that brings history to life
Educational programs and events that engage all ages
Stunning architecture that reflects the spirit of the Old West

museums.content_summary: Nestled in the heart of Grove, Oklahoma, **Har-Ber Village Museum** is a captivating journey through early Americana, featuring over 100 genuine structures and artifacts from the 1800s to the 1950s. This living history museum offers visitors an immersive glimpse into the past, making it a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and families alike.
museums.content_description:
**Har-Ber Village Museum** stands as a testament to the rich cultural heritage of America, showcasing a unique assemblage of over 100 historical buildings and artifacts that tell the story of life in a bygone era. Tucked away on the picturesque shores of Grand Lake, this open-air museum invites you to stroll through time, experiencing the sights and sounds of a self-sustaining community. From the charming blacksmith shop to the rustic schoolhouse, each building in the village is filled with carefully curated items that echo the craftsmanship and ingenuity of earlier generations. Visitors can get up close with an extensive collection of antiques, farm implements, and tools, evoking a sense of nostalgia and wonder.Â 

As you walk through the village, youâ€™ll appreciate its enchanting landscape adorned with lush gardens and beautiful walking paths, perfect for family outings or solo explorations. The museum also hosts a variety of seasonal events and special exhibitions, such as the upcoming **State of Craft 2025** and art showcases by contemporary artists like Alicia Kelly and Shawn Smith, blending traditional craftsmanship with modern interpretations. With engaging educational programs and hands-on activities, **Har-Ber Village Museum** provides visitors not just a look but an experienceâ€”one that connects the past to the present, igniting a passion for history and heritage in all who visit.
content_highlights: Over 100 authentic historical buildings representing early Americana
Extensive collection of antiques, tools, and artifacts from the 19th and 20th centuries
Engaging seasonal events and art exhibitions featuring contemporary artists
Beautifully landscaped grounds with walking paths and gardens
Interactive educational programs for visitors of all ages

museums.content_summary: On the University of Oklahoma campus, the Fred Jones Jr. Museum of Art is a rewarding stop for art lovers who want big ideas without big-city crowds. Expect a thoughtfully scaled museum where changing exhibitions keep the experience freshâ€”especially for visitors interested in contemporary craft and ecological themes in art. With a calm, campus setting and an academic spirit, itâ€™s an ideal place to slow down, look closely, and deepen your understanding of how artists make meaning through materials.
museums.content_description:
Set on the University of Oklahoma campus in Norman, the **Fred Jones Jr. Museum of Art** offers a distinctly collegiate kind of pleasure: a museum where you can spend real time with objects, read the wall texts, and leave feeling youâ€™ve learned somethingâ€”not rushed past it. While itâ€™s a regional institution, its strength is **curatorial focus and changing exhibitions**, which often spotlight how artists think through materials, process, and cultural contextâ€”an especially satisfying lens for visitors who love *craft* and contemporary studio practice.

The museumâ€™s current and upcoming programming (as listed on its website) underscores this emphasis: **â€œThe State of Craft 2025â€** frames making as a serious artistic language, while future shows like **Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right** and **Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies** suggest an interest in todayâ€™s conversations around form, labor, and environmental thinkingâ€”topics that resonate across *contemporary art* and *material-based practices*. For travelers, these rotating presentations mean thereâ€™s often a timely reason to return, and the galleries can feel freshly tuned to what artists are debating right now.

Architecturally and experientially, expect a museum designed for **close looking**: clear sightlines, a contemplative pace, and the pleasant rhythm of a campus visit (pair it with a walk through nearby university buildings and public spaces). Check the calendar before you goâ€”seasonal closures (such as the winter break noted on the site) can affect planningâ€”but for art enthusiasts, itâ€™s a smart, intimate museum stop in Oklahoma with a strong exhibition-driven identity.
content_highlights: Exhibition-driven museum experience with a strong emphasis on contemporary craft and material-based practice
Seasonal signature programming such as â€œThe State of Craft 2025â€ (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026)

museums.content_summary: In the heart of Shawnee, the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art rewards curious art lovers with an intimate, thoughtfully programmed visit. Time your trip around its exhibition calendar for a fresh experience, then linger: this is the kind of museum where detailsâ€”and conversationsâ€”stay with you.
museums.content_description:
**Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art** in Shawnee is a satisfying stop for travelers who prefer museums where you can see everything without rushingâ€”and where the curatorial voice feels personal. Rather than relying on blockbuster crowds, MGMoA builds its appeal through **rotating exhibitions** that bring new work into focus and encourage repeat visits. Recent and upcoming programming points to a strong interest in the handmade and the experimental: **_The State of Craft 2025_** (Dec 5, 2025â€“Jan 24, 2026) highlights contemporary craftâ€™s material intelligence and studio rigor, while solo shows such as **Alicia Kelly: _Roughly Right_** (Feb 6â€“Mar 21, 2026) and **Shawn Smith: _Entangled Ecologies_** (Apr 3â€“May 23, 2026) suggest an engagement with current ideas around process, environment, and form.

For art enthusiasts, the pleasure here is the **visitor experience**: quieter galleries that invite sustained looking, approachable interpretive materials, and a schedule that makes it easy to plan a return around new installations. Check dates before you goâ€”MGMoA notes a **winter break closure (Dec 23, 2025â€“Jan 1, 2026)**â€”and consider pairing your visit with time to absorb the shift in mediums and techniques from show to show. If you love tracing how artists think through materialsâ€”fiber, clay, paper, mixed mediaâ€”this museumâ€™s programming makes Shawnee feel like a worthwhile detour on an Oklahoma art itinerary.

museums.content_summary: The **Gilcrease Museum** in Tulsa is a treasure trove for anyone captivated by American history and art. Renowned for its extensive collection of American Western art and artifacts, this museum not only showcases the rich cultural tapestry of the United States but also offers a stunning architectural experience set against beautiful gardens. A visit here is more than just a museum trip; it's an immersive journey through time.
museums.content_description: **Gilcrease Museum** stands as a unique beacon of American art and history in the heart of Tulsa, Oklahoma. Founded by oilman Thomas Gilcrease in the 1940s, this museum houses one of the most comprehensive collections of *American Western art*, featuring over 20,000 objects that span multiple centuries. As you wander through its galleries, you'll encounter masterpieces by iconic artists such as *Frederic Remington* and *Georgia O'Keeffe*, each piece telling a story of the American experience and spirit. The museum's dedication to preserving the culture, history, and heritage of the American West is palpable in every exhibit. From historical artifacts to contemporary works, there's something for every visitor to appreciate and enjoy.Â Â Additionally, the surrounding gardens are meticulously landscaped and provide a serene backdrop, encouraging reflection on the artworks and their histories.Â Â Beyond the art, the museum also delves into Native American history, showcasing significant collections that illuminate the lives and stories of indigenous peoples throughout time.Â Â Visiting **Gilcrease Museum** not only allows you to witness influential works of art but also to engage deeply with the narratives that shaped a nation. With curated exhibitions and interactive programs, itâ€™s a vibrant hub for learning and discovery.Â Â Whether you're an art aficionado or a casual traveler, your experience will be enriched by the diverse offerings of this exceptional museum.
content_highlights: Extensive collection of American Western art featuring iconic artists
Unique artifacts and historical pieces highlighting Native American history
Beautifully landscaped gardens surrounding the museum for a reflective experience
Engaging temporary exhibitions such as 'The State of Craft 2025' and 'Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right'
Interactive programs and community events that enhance visitor engagement

Come for the mansion-turned-museum experienceâ€”grand rooms, terraces, fountains, and quiet garden pathsâ€”and stay for thoughtfully curated exhibitions that balance regional creativity with broader art-historical conversations. With changing shows highlighting craft and contemporary voices, Philbrook is especially rewarding for visitors who love art in dialogue with architecture, landscape, and place.
museums.content_description:
**Philbrook Museum of Art** is one of Tulsaâ€™s essential stops for art lovers because it offers more than galleries: itâ€™s a complete aesthetic environment. Housed in a historic villa with **Italian Renaissance-inspired architecture**, the museumâ€™s sequence of elegant interior rooms and garden-facing vistas creates a visit that feels part museum, part cultural retreat. The setting encourages slow lookingâ€”moving from intimate galleries to dramatic views across terraces, reflecting pools, and formal plantings that echo the buildingâ€™s symmetry and classical proportions.

Inside, Philbrook shines as a regional art museum with a strong traveler-friendly rhythm: **seasonal exhibitions** and focused projects that spotlight material intelligence and contemporary ideas. Upcoming programming points to this emphasisâ€”*The State of Craft 2025* foregrounds the artistry of making, while solo presentations like **Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right** and **Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies** suggest a commitment to artists engaging with process, environment, and experimentation. For visitors, this means thereâ€™s often something new to discover even on repeat trips, with shows that reward close attention to texture, technique, and concept.

Plan your visit as you would a great house-and-gardens experience: arrive early, move through the galleries, then return outdoors to let the art resonate in the landscape. The museumâ€™s architecture and gardens are not just a backdropâ€”theyâ€™re part of the aesthetic argument, making Philbrook a memorable destination for anyone who enjoys *craft*, contemporary practice, and art experienced through place.
content_highlights: Historic villa setting with Italian Renaissance-inspired architecture and museum galleries woven through grand house interiors
Formal gardens and terraces that turn the visit into an art-and-landscape experienceâ€”ideal for unhurried looking and photography
Exhibition-driven program with recurring emphasis on craft and contemporary practice, including The State of Craft 2025
Solo-artist exhibitions on the horizon, including Alicia Kelly: Roughly Right and Shawn Smith: Entangled Ecologies
A strong regional-museum feel: intimate scale, atmospheric rooms, and a visit that pairs culture with a restorative garden stroll
